title: Ticket #6057: startd cron does not update startd policy ad
description:
Gideon Juve wrote: 

I am having an issue where my startds reject valid claims, and I believe it
is due to a bug somewhere in the startd.

My startds are configured with one slot that is not partitionable.

Each startd also runs a startd cron job that determines the value of the
START expression that looks something like this:

STARTD_CRON_JOBLIST = $(STARTD_CRON_JOBLIST) POLICY
STARTD_CRON_POLICY_MODE = Periodic
STARTD_CRON_POLICY_RECONFIG_RERUN = True
STARTD_CRON_POLICY_PERIOD = 15m
STARTD_CRON_POLICY_EXECUTABLE = get_policy_from_service

Including:

STARTD_CRON_AUTOPUBLISH = Always

And the START expression is set like this:

START = Policy

And the value of Policy is updated by the cron job.

When the policy needs to change, I reconfig the machine to get it to pull
down its new policy from a central service.

Occasionally, the policy change will cause the START expression to evaluate
to TRUE when it was previously FALSE. When that happens, the collector
(almost) immediately gets a new ad for the machine and it gets matched with
a job. However, the startd rejects the claim for the remainder of
UPDATE_INTERVAL (set to 300 seconds) until the startd reevaluates and
republishes its ad again. In the rejection message in the log it prints the
previous machine ad (not the one that it just sent to the collector).

This leads me to believe that there is some internal state that is not
getting updated when the cron job causes a new ad to be published.
Eventually that state is updated the next time the startd publishes its ad.

This is using 8.4.2 on Ubuntu 16.04.

Preliminary investigation reveals the following problem: the startd cron job calls ResMgr::update_all() when STARTD_CRON_AUTOPUBLISH is set. ResMgr::update_all() ends up calling Resource::publish_for_update(), which calls Resource::publish() with the mask A_ALL_PUB, which calls RsMgr::adlist_publish() with the same mask. However ResMgr::adlist_publish() publishes ads (including the cron job ad) if and only if the mask has the public and update bits sets, and A_ALL_PUB does not set the update bit.
remarks:
2016-Dec-19 16:17:42 by tlmiller:
It remains to be seen if this causes the reported problem, which on the surface appears to be the opposite issue.

2016-Dec-20 14:47:56 by tlmiller:
Turns out that A_ALL_PUB does include A_UPDATE -- just indirectly.

The actual problem is that update_all() doesn't actually update everything. There's a completely different code path to actually update the ads the startd actually uses to evaluate policy expressions. Patch demonstrated locally, in testing.

2016-Dec-21 14:13:10 by tlmiller:
Build IDs 391631 (8.4) and 391513 (master) were the tests.
